Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Atomization-Based Cutting Fluid and CO2 Spray System for Machining Titanium Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The collaborative research to be conducted under this award is directed toward a more fundamental understanding of an atomized-based cutting fluid and carbon dioxide spray cooling and lubrication application system for machining of titanium alloys. The specific objectives are to: (i) establish an understanding of the film formation behavior on a stationary surface from the atomized cutting fluids, and its penetration characteristics at the cutting interface during titanium machining; (ii) better understand the temperature distribution and the heat removal characteristics throughout the cutting interface; (iii) study the effects of spray parameters, spray unit orientation angle, and fluid properties (for example, surface tension and viscosity) and the application of carbon dioxide as a droplet carrier gas on the machining performances including tool wear, cutting temperature, and chip formation. These objectives will be realized through the execution of three principal tasks: (1) model the film formation behavior of the atomized cutting fluid droplets and their penetration to the tool-chip interface; (2) predict the temperature distribution at the cutting interface under the atomized cutting fluid spray conditions; and (3) develop a process plan for an effective lubrication and cooling application during machining of titanium alloys. The validation of model predictions of the fluid film characteristics including film thickness and film pressure will be accomplished by employing the probe pressure sensors, and a high resolution camera. A hardware testbed will be developed at the site of collaborative partner, TechSolve, Inc., for the technology capability testing and evaluation.

The enhanced understanding of the tribological behavior of the atomized droplets at the tool/chip/work-piece interfaces will drive advances in tool design and manufacturing and improvement in other processes such as "minimum quantity lubricant" in grinding, machining and rolling. As the atomized-based cutting fluid spray system uses significantly small amount of electrical energy, this cooling system will help in saving electrical energy for those existing cooling techniques that operate a large fluid pump. Further, the use of carbon dioxide in this cutting fluid spray system can lead to developing many environmentally-friendly manufacturing processes. Efforts will be made to boost the participation of members from under-represented groups in this research by proactively participating in several on-campus/off-campus programs, including Women in Engineering Program and Minority Engineering Program.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of the research conducted for this award was to understand the fluid film penetration and the heat removal characteristics in an atomized cutting fluid (ACF) spray environment that is integrated with a carbon dioxide (CO2) delivery system for the machining of titanium alloys. The specific objectives of the project were to:

1. better understand both the ACF spray-produced film formation behavior on a stationary surface and the penetration mechanism of the film at the tool-chip interface during titanium machining,

2. better understand the temperature distribution and the heat removal characteristics throughout the interface for the ACF spray system, and

3. conduct parametric studies that enable the development of an effective ACF spray system and a process plan for improved titanium machining performance in terms of cutting tool temperature, tool wear and chip formation.

Two partner organizations have contributed to this research: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign (UIUC) and TechSolve, Inc.

The outcomes described below are part of TechSolve's contributions. For an overall view of all the outcomes, the UIUC report should also be consulted.

Significant outcomes of the research conducted at TechSolve include:

1. Design and development of an ACF spray system to be used in turning or milling applications. An initial and second design solutions were used to conduct the project work. The second design iteration was an improved version of the first prototype, with a more robust structure and operation, a smaller footprint and a reduced number of inputs.

2. Results of evaluation and verification cutting tests conducted for development and assessment of ACF spray system performance. The roughing and finish cutting tests conducted on Ti-6Al-4V have proven that the ACF system can lead to similar or better machining performance when comparing with the flood fluid supply solution.

3. Optimization of ACF spray system settings and setup parameters to allow for an increased tool life and finished part quality. The design of experiments executed with the ACF spray system allowed identification of optimal parameters  for a cutting process with respect to nozzle geometry, gas pressure and flow, impingement angle, and distance from the tool tip.

4. The project provided professional development to the engineers and machinists involved, allowing them to gain a deeper understanding of the machining of Ti-6Al-4V alloy and the effects of the atomization-based cutting fluid technology.

5. Through publications, presentations, and open house activities, broad public awareness of the ACF spray technology and its potential advantages was achieved.

The outcomes of this research advance the knowledge in the area of atomization of metalworking fluids, fluid film formation at the cutting tool - chip interface, and ability to conduct efficient cutting operations using a reduced quantity of fluid.

Also, the outcomes of this research have broad societal impact as they are advancing the knowledge and progress towards reducing the utilization of hazardous materials, becoming more environmentally friendly, and reducing the energy consumption for the machining-based manufacturing processes.


Last Modified: 10/30/2016
Modified by: Radu Pavel
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main focus of the research conducted for this award was to understand the fluid film penetration and the heat removal characteristics in an atomized cutting fluid (ACF) spray environment that is integrated with a carbon dioxide (CO2) delivery system for the machining of titanium alloys. The specific objectives of the project were to: 1. better understand both the ACF spray-produced film formation behavior on a stationary surface and the penetration mechanism of the film at the tool-chip interface during titanium machining, 2. better understand the temperature distribution and the heat removal characteristics throughout the interface for the ACF spray system, and 3. conduct parametric studies that enable the development of an effective ACF spray system and a process plan for improved titanium machining performance in terms of cutting tool temperature, tool wear and chip formation. Two partner organizations have contributed to this research: University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign (UIUC) and TechSolve, Inc. The outcomes described below are part of TechSolve's contributions. For an overall view of all the outcomes, the UIUC report should also be consulted. Significant outcomes of the research conducted at TechSolve include: 1. Design and development of an ACF spray system to be used in turning or milling applications. An initial and second design solutions were used to conduct the project work. The second design iteration was an improved version of the first prototype, with a more robust structure and operation, a smaller footprint and a reduced number of inputs. 2. Results of evaluation and verification cutting tests conducted for development and assessment of ACF spray system performance. The roughing and finish cutting tests conducted on Ti-6Al-4V have proven that the ACF system can lead to similar or better machining performance when comparing with the flood fluid supply solution. 3. Optimization of ACF spray system settings and setup parameters to allow for an increased tool life and finished part quality. The design of experiments executed with the ACF spray system allowed identification of optimal parameters for a cutting process with respect to nozzle geometry, gas pressure and flow, impingement angle, and distance from the tool tip. 4. The project provided professional development to the engineers and machinists involved, allowing them to gain a deeper understanding of the machining of Ti-6Al-4V alloy and the effects of the atomization-based cutting fluid technology. 5. Through publications, presentations, and open house activities, broad public awareness of the ACF spray technology and its potential advantages was achieved. The outcomes of this research advance the knowledge in the area of atomization of metalworking fluids, fluid film formation at the cutting tool - chip interface, and ability to conduct efficient cutting operations using a reduced quantity of fluid. Also, the outcomes of this research have broad societal impact as they are advancing the knowledge and progress towards reducing the utilization of hazardous materials, becoming more environmentally friendly, and reducing the energy consumption for the machining-based manufacturing processes.
